Description: Scarab carved from stone; underside bearing incised hieroglyphic inscription arranged vertically, difficult to read since only an old drawing is available for this scarab: at the top a seated sphinx with possibly a hes-vase or Hm sign above its back; at bottom, three hieroglyphic signs probably wadj column and ankh signs framing a Heb-sed or p-sign; top left part and right side of scarab damaged.
Curator's comments: Scarab not yet located, published by Petrie (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVIII, no. 177). The inscription could start with "beloved of Amun" (as a possible parallel for the inscription: Hornung and Staehelin 1976, 256 , pl. 33, no. 325). The scarab Egyptian Museum in Cairo JE33593.6 seems very similar to that one according to the description on the museum's registers. However, the scarab JE33593.6 was discovered by Hogarth in 1899 and is slightly different from Petrie's drawing. The fact that two scarabs presents a similar inscription could possibly indicate a local production. This suggestion cannot be confirmed in the absence of photographs for both scarabs. Hornung, E., Staehelin, E. 1976. Skarabäen und andere Siegelamulette aus Basler Sammlungen, Ägyptische Denkmäler in der Schweiz I. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I., 1884–5 (third memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVIII, no. 177)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OA.73) (phase 3)
